title: 160+ Trivia Questions and Answers for Senior Citizens

steps.title: Get things going with a few easy questions.
steps.content: Get things going with a few easy questions. When doing trivia with seniors, it’s important to accommodate a wide range of ability levels. Some seniors may have a harder time with complicated questions, so you’ll want to include a fair amount of simple options, too. This gives everyone a chance to enjoy themselves and score some points for their team. Here are some examples: Question: Who sang the hit song “Can’t Help Falling in Love”? Answer: Elvis Presley Question: What was the first name of President John F. Kennedy’s wife? Answer: Jacqueline/Jackie. Question: Who was the first president of the United States? Answer: George Washington Question: What TV series starred Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz? Answer: I Love Lucy Question: Who was the first man to walk on the moon? Answer: Neil Armstrong Question: Which English rock band formed in 1960 is named after an insect? Answer: The Beatles Question: A man in a top hat with a mustache is the mascot of which classic board game? Answer: Monopoly Question: What is the capital of France? Answer: Paris Question: Who wrote the novel To Kill a Mockingbird ? Answer: Harper Lee Question: What is the chemical symbol for water? Answer: H 2 O

steps.title: Questions about the 1960s are sure to delight seniors.
steps.content: Questions about the 1960s are sure to delight seniors. Depending on the year they were born, the seniors at your trivia night were likely tweens or teens during the ’60s. This means that questions about 1960s pop culture will probably be pretty fun and nostalgic for them! Here are some examples to try out: Question: The four members of The Beatles were Paul McCartney, John Lennon, Ringo Starr, and who else? Answer: George Harrison Question: Who was the U.S. president in the year 1960? Answer: Dwight D. Eisenhower Question: What was the name of Audrey Hepburn’s character in the 1964 movie My Fair Lady ? Answer: Eliza Doolittle Question: What was the name of the first artificial satellite launched by the Soviet Union? Answer: Sputnik 1 Question: Which U.S. president was assassinated in 1963? Answer: John F. Kennedy Question: What popular music festival took place in 1969? Answer: Woodstock Question: Which famous civil rights leader gave his famous “I Have a Dream” speech in 1963? Answer: Martin Luther King Jr. Question: Who sang the 1967 hit “Brown Eyed Girl”? Answer: Van Morrison Question: What’s the nickname of the iconic British model from the 1960s whose real name is Lesley Lawson? Answer: Twiggy Question: In what year did Neil Armstrong become the first man to walk on the moon? Answer: 1969 Question: Who was the lead singer of The Supremes in the 1960s? Answer: Diana Ross Question: During the 1960s, rock bands from England became very popular. What was the nickname given to this phenomenon? Answer: The British Invasion Question: Which singer played Catwoman in the Batman TV series in 1967? Answer: Eartha Kitt Question: Which 1967 musical features the songs “Aquarius” and “Good Morning Starshine”? Answer: Hair Question: What was the name of the mission that put the first humans on the moon? Answer: Apollo 11 Question: Which iconic 1960 horror film featured the Bates Motel? Answer: Psycho Question: Which jazz legend released “What a Wonderful World” in 1967? Answer: Louis Armstrong

steps.content: Try out some fun questions about the 1950s. Answer: The Barbie doll Question: Dr. Jonas Salk created a successful vaccine for which disease in 1952? Answer: Polio Question: What was Marilyn Monroe’s real name? Answer: 1956 Question: Which famous baseball player married Marilyn Monroe in 1954? Answer: Joe DiMaggio Question: Which American actress became a princess after marrying the prince of Monaco in 1956? Answer: Grace Kelly Question: Which music and lyrics duo wrote the songs in the 1956 movie musical Carousel ? Answer: Rogers and Hammerstein Question: Who wrote the 1951 novel The Catcher in the Rye ? Answer: J.D. Sallinger Question: The Tonight Show premiered in 1954. Who was its first host? Answer: Steve Allen Question: Les Paul is associated with which instrument? Answer: The guitar

steps.title: Take things way back with trivia about the 1940s.
steps.content: Take things way back with trivia about the 1940s. If you’ve got some seniors in their 80s or 90s in the mix, they’ll likely be excited about a few fun pop culture questions about the 1940s. Here are some awesome examples to try out: Question: What year did World War II begin? Answer: 1939 Question: Which iconic mystery author wrote And Then There Were None ? Answer: Agatha Christie Question: Who was the U.S. president at the start of World War II? Answer: Franklin D. Roosevelt Question: Which actress became the first African American to win an Academy Award in 1940? Answer: Hattie McDaniel Question: What surprise attack led to the U.S. becoming involved in WWII? Answer: Pearl Harbor Question: What 1940 animated Disney movie was about a puppet whose nose grew when he lied? Answer: Pinocchio Question: Who became the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in 1940? Answer: Winston Churchill Question: Which actress starred as Scarlett O’Hara in the movie Gone with the Wind ? Answer: Vivien Leigh Question: In which year was the microwave oven invented? Answer: 1945 Question: What was the actual date of the WWII beach invasion known as D-Day? Answer: June 6, 1944 Question: Who was the first African American baseball player to break the color line in Major League Baseball in 1947? Answer: Jackie Robinson Question: What date was called “a date which will live in infamy” by Franklin D. Roosevelt? Answer: December 7, 1941. Question: Which countries were known as the Axis Powers during World War II? Answer: Germany, Italy, Japan

Here are some example questions: Question: What actress starred in Casablanca with Humphrey Bogart? Answer: Ingrid Bergman Question: Who directed the iconic 1960 movie Psycho ? Answer: Alfred Hitchcock Question: What is the name of Dorothy’s dog in The Wizard of Oz ? Answer: Toto Question: “Well, nobody’s perfect,” is the final line from which 1959 classic starring Marilyn Monroe?” Answer: Some Like It Hot Question: Which actress played Holly Golightly in Breakfast at Tiffany’s ? steps.title: Get a little intellectual with questions about literature or the arts.
steps.content: Get a little intellectual with questions about literature or the arts. These types of questions are staples at trivia nights, and for good reason. They’re a chance for players to show off how well-read or educated they are, and they might even get a chance to talk about their favorite book or artist. Here are some fun questions to try out: Question: Who painted the Mona Lisa ? Answer: Leonardo da Vinci Question: Which classic novel features the characters Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy? Answer: Pride and Prejudice Question: Who composed the music for The Nutcracker ? Answer: Tchaikovsky Question: Which artist is famous for his “Campbell’s Soup Can” artwork from the 1960s? Answer: Andy Warhol Question: In what city was William Shakespeare born? Answer: Stratford-upon-Avon Question: Which artist painted The Starry Night ? Answer: Vincent Van Gogh Question: Who wrote the play Death of a Salesman ? Answer: Arthur Miller Question: Which novel is told from the perspective of a young girl named Scout Finch? Answer: To Kill a Mockingbird Question: Which artist painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel? Answer: Michelangelo Question: What novel begins with the line, “It was the best of times, it was the worst of times”? Answer: A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens Question: Who wrote The Lord of the Rings trilogy? Answer: J.R.R. Tolkien Question: What was the pen name of the author Samuel Clemens, who wrote the classic Adventures of Huckleberry Finn ? Answer: Mark Twain Question: What Spanish artist was famous for a painting titled The Persistence of Memory, which featured melting clocks? Answer: Salvador Dalí Question: Which playwright wrote A Streetcar Named Desire ? Answer: Tennessee Williams Question: Which novel by George Orwell is set in a society under constant surveillance by Big Brother? Answer: 1984 Question: Who composed The Four Seasons? Answer: Vivaldi Question: Which Broadway musical was based on the Victor Hugo novel about the June Rebellion of 1832 in France? Answer: Les Misérables

steps.title: Amp up the difficulty with a few tricky science questions.
steps.content: Amp up the difficulty with a few tricky science questions. Test their knowledge (and how well they paid attention in science class!) with these interesting questions about things like space, biology, and chemistry. Question: What is the only metal that’s liquid at room temperature? Answer: Mercury Question: Which scientist is famous for the theory of evolution? Answer: Charles Darwin Question: What’s the largest planet in our solar system? Answer: Jupiter Question: Which scientist is famous for his 3 laws of motion? Answer: Isaac Newton Question: What is a scientist who studies weather called? Answer: A meteorologist. Question: How many chambers are there in the human heart? Answer: 4 Question: What is the scientific name for the process plants use to make food from sunlight? Answer: Photosynthesis Question: Which gas is most abundant in the Earth’s atmosphere? Answer: Nitrogen Question: What is the largest organ in the human body? Answer: The skin. Question: At what temperature does water boil? Answer: 212 degrees Fahrenheit (100 degrees Celsius) Question: How many elements are there on the periodic table? Answer: 118 Question: How many bones are there in the human body? Answer: 206 Question: What’s the largest desert on Earth? Answer: Antarctica Question: What are the three layers of the Earth? Answer: Crust, mantle, core Question: What blood type is known as the “universal donor”? Answer: O negative

steps.title: Choose question topics that resonate with seniors.
steps.content: Choose question topics that resonate with seniors. When you’re throwing a trivia night for older guests, it’s important to think about their interests and the type of media they like. For instance, seniors may not relate to questions about Gen Z or millennial pop culture. Instead, try to stick to categories that are nostalgic and fun for them. If your senior guests grew up in the 1940s or 1950s, for example, questions from these decades are sure to be entertaining for them!

steps.title: Include a wide range of difficulty levels.
steps.content: Include a wide range of difficulty levels. Some seniors in attendance might struggle a bit with their memory or cognitive abilities, so they may enjoy simpler questions more. On the other hand, seniors who aren’t experiencing any cognitive changes might be looking for tough questions to exercise their brains and keep their minds sharp . Because of all this, it’s important to include questions with easy, medium, and hard difficulty levels, so that all seniors in attendance can enjoy themselves.

steps.title: Try to choose interesting, unique questions.
steps.content: Try to choose interesting, unique questions. “People love interesting things [..] I structure all my questions around that concept—things people don’t realize they want to know,” explains Cohen. “Instead of asking a dry fact, offer a funny or clever clue to help people figure it out. People love feeling smart when they solve a tricky clue,” he says. For example, a question about the number of words in a Charles Dickens novel might be tricky, but it’s not all that interesting. Cohen offers an example of a literature question that’s equally tricky but way more fascinating and unique: Question: Ray Bradbury's classic sci-fi novel "Fahrenheit 451" was serialized in three 1954 issues of which magazine, lending credence to people who claimed they "only bought it for the articles"? Answer : Playboy.

steps.title: Figure out the logistics to suit everybody’s needs and abilities.
steps.content: Figure out the logistics to suit everybody’s needs and abilities. When you start your senior game night, you’ll want everything to be clear and planned out, so that there’s no confusion. For example, if some seniors are hard of hearing, you’ll probably want to use a microphone to ask questions. Similarly, if some seniors have trouble with their eyesight, you’ll want to make sure you have written materials in larger fonts. It’s all about making sure everyone’s comfortable and taken care of, so they can all have an awesome time.

steps.title: Create a fun, welcoming atmosphere.
steps.content: Create a fun, welcoming atmosphere. Remember, a trivia session for seniors is about having fun and connecting with others. To facilitate this, have some yummy snacks and beverages on hand and play some good music. If you’re throwing your trivia party at someone’s house, Cohen recommends splitting guests up into teams for some friendly competition, and he also recommends playing in the backyard if it’s warm outside. All of these things come together to create a great vibe for your trivia night!

steps.title: Trivia isn’t just a fun way to pass the time.
steps.content: Trivia isn’t just a fun way to pass the time. It actually has some significant benefits for the health and wellness for seniors, including: Keeping their minds healthy: Trivia is an enjoyable way for seniors to test their memories and exercise their brains . Research shows that a higher level of cognitive activity can delay the onset of dementia, so brainy activities like trivia can be super helpful for seniors. Research also shows that learning and mastering new skills helps keep seniors sharp as they age. Social connection is essential to boost seniors’ moods and fight against mental health issues like depression, stress, and anxiety.
